fields.description:
h3. Summary
User groups cannot be added as Reviewers.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a group ({{test_group}} in the screenshots below)
# Make sure that the group has access to Crucible (see the "Access to Crucible" flag described on [Global permissions|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/global-permissions-812222809.html])
# Create a review
# Start typing the {{test_group}} string to locate the group

h3. Expected Results
The group {{test_group}} is +listed in the drop down+ like version 3.10.3:
!CRUC7676_group_listed.png|width=400px!

h3. Actual Results
The group {{test_group}} is +*not* listed in the drop down+.
!CRUC7676_group_not_listed.png|width=400px!
fields.summary: User groups cannot be added as Reviewers because they are not listed in the Reviewers drop down

fields.description:
Change the Branch Review Auto-Update default state to "Off"

*updated:*
Allow customers to configure the default Branch Review Auto-Update state
fields.summary: Allow customers to configure the default Branch Review Auto-Update state

fields.description:
Currently the {{[/rest-service/search-v1/reviewsForIssue|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/3.9.1/wadl/crucible.html#rest-service:search-v1:reviewsForIssue]}} REST API endpoint just retrieves reviews that have the JIRA issue key being searched for as "Linked Issue".

It should also retrieve reviews that have the JIRA issue key being searched for mentioned in review comments, title or description.
fields.summary: REST API: reviewsForIssue should include JIRA issues mentioned in review comments, title or description

fields.description:
When creating a branch review with "Auto update" turned {{Off}} a message is displayed saying that no branch was added to the review.

 !Add branch-error.jpg|thumbnail! 

How to reproduce:

# Have branch1 that has commits ahead of branch2.
# Create Review.
# Choose Branches.
# Set {{Branch to review}} to *branch1*.
# Set {{Branched from}} to *branch2*.
# *Add branch*
# Set {{Auto update}} *Off*.
# *Update now* (a message will show stating that there are no commits for *branch1* > *branch2*
# *Start Review*
# Message pops up "You haven't added the selected branch to the review" with options "Stay on the Page" or "Leave this Page".

*Workaround:*
Click *Leave the Page*.  All commit files in the branch will be attached.
fields.summary: No branch selected error when creating branch review

fields.description:
Nowadays Crucible projects can only be deleted one by one. There should be a way of deleting them in bulk, by adding a checkbox to each project in the projects list, and a delete button at the bottom of the page.

h3. Workaround
As a workaround to automate deletion of many projects REST endpoints can be used, see DELETE method for https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/fecru.html#rest-service-fecru:admin:projects:key
fields.summary: Allow deleting projects in bulk

fields.description:
h4. Problem
Crucible e-mail notifications contain links to images that are behind authentication. If the e-mail client used does not authenticated to Crucible, they will not display:
!reviewReminder.jpg!

The URL that is being used, for example: [https://FISHEYE_URL/static/nh2qf9/2static/images/email/single_crucible_40.png]

h4. Suggestion
The images are best to be embedded to the e-mail so that they can be displayed, even if the e-mail is viewed offline.
fields.summary: Images broken in Crucible notifications

fields.description:
Starting from Crucible 4.0.1 I see that whenever I type @ and the first characters of a user's display name or alias I get nothing.
If I type first characters of the second word in the display name I get a match.

Please see the attached recording. Please note: once Crucible finds the user using the second word in the display name, first name starts to work as well.

We're running Crucible on Postgres. Users are managed internally by Crucible.
fields.summary: @user_name doesn't match first name or alias

fields.description:
Crucible gives the option to enter draft comments, however currently customers have to go to each draft comment and post them individually one at a time. Supposing a review with dozens of draft comments from a single user, it would require some manual work for that user to go through all draft comments and post them.

It would be much easier if it were possible to post all draft comments added by the current user in the current review at once, in a single mouse click in a {{"Post My Draft Comments"}} button.

h2. Workaround

There is an existing feature that may be used as a workaround.  When reviewers click "Complete" button, a prompt will be shown explaining there are draft comments left.  User can decided to publish all those drafts with one click then.  This approach should work fine in case reviewer is ready to mark the review as completed, otherwise user would need to click "Uncomplete" right after to indicate his review is not yet complete.  Note, when implementing this workaround ensure reviewers are given "Uncomplete" permission in permission scheme.
fields.summary: Allow posting all draft comments at once

fields.description:
Hi
We all agree that a JIRA ticket would transition if its linked code reviews are reviewed and closed. If one of these code reviews is open, then the JIRA issue shouldn't be transitioned.
However, there is an issue (in my opinion) for it: What happens when a linked code review is at Draft, Abandoned or Summarized state? What it seems is that there is a code change committed against the ticket and its Crucible code review is created but is on Draft state. At the JIRA ticket side, there are transitions that shouldn't appear because of the code review is not closed regardless of being reviewed or not.

Is there a way that at JIRA workflow transition, set a condition that the ticket shouldn't be transitioned when at least one of the code reviews is open, draft, abandoned, or summarized.

Thanks
fields.summary: Workflow condition in terms of non-open/close code review statuses

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When viewing the diff as "Side by side diff", if the code on the left window is very wide it is difficult to see any code on the right window being diffed. Dragging the bottom slider then moves the left window away.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Make the bar (border) between the two diff windows draggable to left or right.
fields.summary: Adjustable Side by side diff window in Crucible reviews

fields.description:
Crucible 2 had a UI that was more conducive to a developer workflow. When you scrolled down the file - ONLY the file scrolled. Not the header. Not the tree on the left - just that frame.  That was a quality UI experience.

WIth 3.0 came new css that basically 'ruined' the UIUX. Now when I scroll down - my tree (on the left) moves. i could almost live with that - though it's bad UIUX. The kicker is all the buttons to 'act' on the review are all the way at the top of the page - and since the header now scrolls when i scroll down the buttons disappear. Forcing me to slog all the way back UP the page again to click any of the buttons. That's annoying - and bad UIUX. Not to mention the header is GIGANTIC now in comparison - full of worthless whitespace. I'd be quite happy to provide screen shots if you like - but I'm betting you know what I mean.

I'd really like to see this fixed. I posted on the community forum but the answer there was "a best effort" to assuage my pain.

Can this please be addressed?

I'd be happy having a choice of a few themes? old 'compact' theme - new 'touch friendly' (or whatever it was done for) theme etc.
fields.summary: Bring back the usable UI header - and more compact CSS

fields.description:
Adding a git repository (bitbucket) fails when crucible is installed on Windows.  Marked this as a blocker since i cannot add a repository - and I have no suitable workaround

Here is a link to the community site where someone posted this affects 4.0.1 https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/37860322/crucible-not-connecting-to-self-hosted-git-repo-ubuntu-server and which I added comments

i tried to search for this bug being filed, but didn't find it... sorry if this is a dupe

Steps to reproduce:
* download for windows os: atlassian-crucible-4.0.2-x64.exe or crucible-4.0.3.zip (the two installs I tested)
* run installer - or unzip the zip (i wanted to see if it was a problem with the installer only)
* make it through the 'add license' steps and get to "add repository"
* repository type: git
* name the repository
* click next
* enter the bitbucket url - i used: git@bitbucket.org:my-user/my-repository.git (obviously changed the real url)
* path is empty
* git authentication -> authentication style "Upload private key for ssh" (i KNOW this key works, tested it manually via CLI)
* choose the proper file
* click 'test connection'
* observe: {code}Fisheye is using 'C:\apps\cygwin64\bin\ssh.exe' to authenticate with SSH authenticated repositories.
Error testing connection.
Error talking to repository: 

D:\Atlassian\downloads\crucible-4.0.3\fecru-4.0.3\bin\fe-ssh.sh: line 7: exec: C:\apps\cygwin64\bin\ssh.exe: not found
fatal: Could not read from remote repository.

Please make sure you have the correct access rights
and the repository exists.

at com.atlassian.fisheye.git.GitScmConfig.testConnection(GitScmConfig.java:120)
at com.cenqua.fisheye.RepositoryConfig.testConnection(RepositoryConfig.java:428)
at com.atlassian.fisheye.spi.admin.impl.DefaultRepositoryAdminService.testConnectionFor(DefaultRepositoryAdminService.java:862)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)
at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(Unknown Source)
Connection failed.{code}

as noted in the link -  fe-ssh.sh is being invoked even though this is a windows server - is that intentional?
fields.summary: Add Git Repository fails on windows

fields.description:
In prior versions of Crucible it was possible to select a group in reviewer drop down list. Group would get expanded and all group members would be shown as reviewers.

After upgrade to Crucible 4.0.1 I cannot see any of the internal user groups when selecting reviewers, nor can I search for it.

We're running Crucible in standalone mode with PostgresDB. Users are managed by Crucible's internal directory.

h3. Summary

# Create a review
# Add one revision to it
# View a file
# Click on the revision number on the blame column

h3. Expected Results

2016-03-17 14:31:46,723 INFO  - 404: FishEye is not enabled referer=null

2016-03-17 14:35:44,427 INFO  [qtp231202600-623 ] fisheye ServletUtils-send404 - 404: Page not found referer=http://localhost:8060/cru/CR-1

Apply a FishEye license as suggested in [404: FishEye is not enabled referer=null|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fishkb/404-fisheye-is-not-enabled-referer-null-315327310.html].

Actual Bugs:

# In graph of the repository (https://crucible.domain.com/graph/PRJ-TST) the commit is displayed using *Date* instead of *Commit Date* (see in attachment 3 on the right side the timeline goes "1 March", then "11 Feb", then "1 March" again)

fields.description:
h3. Steps to reproduce

# Create 2 repositories e.g. _r1_ and _r2_
# Create project which has default repo _r1_
#  Create review in given project try to add branch content from repo _r2_

fields.description:
When updating (either manually or automatically), a branch review, where the base branch has been removed, the lookup to find commits on the reviewed branch, but excluding the base branch will consider every commit in the repository (up to the sanity limit of 50000).

If the updated branch does have some new revisions, looking up the start revisions for those (findStartRevisions) will consider every single ancestor of each revision, that is on one of the commits retrieved in the previous step. 

The latter part might visit revisions multiple times for revisions with complex ancestries, and does an eager load of the revisions, potentially consuming a lot of memory, and causing the instance to die with an OutOfMemoryError.
fields.summary: Updating a branch review where the base branch has been deleted causes the traversal of the entire repository
User can see project on project list but when entering receives: The requested resource cannot be found.

fields.description:
h3. Crucible Project Configuration:
# Three users involved: {{user1}}, {{user2}} and {{user3}}
# Edited the {{default}} Permission Scheme in order to make the Reviewer role be able to approve and reject a review:
||Permissions||Users / Groups / Review Roles||
|Approve|Review Roles: Moderator, Reviewer|
|Reject|Review Roles: Moderator, Reviewer|
# Edited the {{CR}} Crucible project and:
** Ensured that it is using the {{default}} Permission Scheme.
** Enabled the Moderator role for that project, selecting {{user1}} as default moderator
** Selected {{user2}} and {{user3}} as Default reviewers

h3. First test, with a Default Moderator selected

*Review {{CR-1}} created with {{user1}}:*
# The {{Add content}} screen shows buttons {{Add More Content}}, {{Edit Details}}, {{Abandon Review}}, {{Start Review}} and {{Done}}
# Clicked {{Done}} and the default reviewers {{user2}} and {{user3}} were added to the review. {{user1}} shows up as {{Author & Moderator}}
# Clicked {{Start Review}} and it was sent to reviewers {{user2}} and {{user3}}
# Logged out, then logged in as {{user2}} / {{user3}} and accessed {{CR-1}}, whose status is {{OPEN}}.
** *Expected:* see {{Approve}} and {{Reject}} buttons, but none got displayed. Just {{Complete}} button was displayed.

*Review {{CR-2}} created with {{user3}}:*
# The {{Add content}} screen shows buttons {{Add More Content}}, {{Edit Details}}, {{Abandon Review}}, {{Send to Moderator}} and {{Done}}
# Clicked {{Done}}, and {{user3}} shows up only as Author, {{user1}} shows up as Moderator, and {{user2}} shows up as Reviewer.
** *Expected:* as reviewers are allowed to Approve and Reject reviews, {{user3}} should not need to click {{Send to Moderator}} for approval / rejection.

h3. Second test, keeping the Moderator role enabled but removing {{user1}} as Default moderator on that Crucible project
*Review {{CR-3}} created with {{user1}}:*
# The {{Add content}} screen shows buttons {{Add More Content}}, {{Edit Details}}, {{Abandon Review}}, {{Start Review}} and {{Done}}
# Clicked {{Done}} and the default reviewers {{user2}} and {{user3}} were added to the review. {{user1}} shows up as {{Author & Moderator}}
# Clicked {{Start Review}} and it was sent to reviewers {{user2}} and {{user3}}
# Logged out, then logged in as {{user2}} / {{user3}} and accessed {{CR-3}}, whose status is {{OPEN}}.
** *Expected:* see {{Approve}} and {{Reject}} buttons, but none got displayed. Just {{Complete}} button was displayed.

*Review {{CR-4}} created with {{user2}}:*
# The {{Add content}} screen shows buttons {{Add More Content}}, {{Edit Details}}, {{Abandon Review}}, {{Start Review}} and {{Done}}
# Clicked {{Done}}, and {{user2}} shows up as Author and Moderator, {{user3}} shows up as Reviewer, and {{user1}} was not listed
** *Expected:* see {{Approve}} and {{Reject}} buttons, but none got displayed. Just {{Edit Details}} and {{Start Review}} buttons were displayed.
# Clicked {{Start Review}}
# Logged out, then logged in with {{user3}}
** *Expected:* see {{Approve}} and {{Reject}} buttons, but none got displayed. Just {{Complete}} button was displayed.

h3. Result:
It doesn't matter if there is a Moderator selected or not. Reviewers cannot ever Approve / Reject reviews.
fields.summary: Reviewer Role allowed in permission scheme to Approve / Reject reviews cannot do that

fields.description:
This is a request to allow a configurable limit to be set on files reviewed using Crucible, such that when these limits are exceeded, the syntax coloring will be automatically disabled, and a warning might be included at the top that specifies that due to the very large file content, syntax coloring has been disabled to improve performance.

Crucible performance when browsing reviews that include changes to large files can be very slow. For changes to files with 30,000 lines of C/C++ code with "10 lines of context" it can take 5 seconds or more with a fast web browser, and with "full context" it can take 30 seconds (real measurements performed today for a file in a sample review today). Using Chrome reduced the time to 25 seconds, but this is still a very long time for users to wait in order to see a response to their page clicks. Using Chrome did reduce the time to 25 seconds, but this is still very long.

In analysis we have done, I believe a majority of the time is spent in the web browser parsing and generating the DOM, and then rendering the DOM to the page. In the existing tool that the users are using, it does not do syntax coloring. Taking a look at the DOM, I see that the Crucible DOM is very rich, with all keyword, identifiers, and other such symbols configured with varying CSS classes. For 30,000 lines of rich text, it can take a lot of processing to lay out the page. For some of our users, Firefox will give timeout warnings, and for others of our users, the browser might crash and seem to never come back. The users blame Crucible, because their existing tool that supports these files just fine apparently.

In Bitbucket, which we also use, I see that Atlassian has implemented a number of alternate behaviours when certain configurable limits are reached, in order to maintain the health of the instance. The service can be degraded while still allowing it to provide significant value. In Crucible, I have also noticed improvements to dashboards and such where if a particular query takes too long to complete, it will return early results and warn the user that the query did not complete in time, and that control is being returned to the user early rather than continuing to wait for the full results.

I would like a site-wide configurable limit to be set on files reviewed using Crucible, such that when these limits are exceeded, the syntax coloring will be automatically disabled, and a warning might be included at the top that specifies that due to the very large file content, syntax coloring has been disabled to improve performance.

For example, the limit might be "# of lines in a source file", and it might default to 5,000 lines. If the number of lines is less than the limit, than the file would be rendered with full syntax colored enabled. If the number of lines is greater than the limit, the file would be rendered as simple lines of text without any special syntax coloring enabled, and a warning at the top would explain to the user why this has happened.

Please put aside judgement around why files are 30,000 lines long. The fact is, we have software projects that include files such as these, that do get changed, and we need to be able to effectively review them in a code review tool, often with full context. In these cases, I would prefer a careful degrading of the feature set to something that might have acceptable performance, rather than having Crucible seem to fail, and having users refuse to use Crucible because their other tool works fine with 30,000 line files and Crucible does not.
fields.summary: Disable syntax coloring for large files to address rendering performance problems

fields.description:
Once review is started, the progress of each participant is tracked - so it is tracked what file revisions and comments were read.

This is not possible for draft reviews though, which seems wrong.  Typically, when I'm preparing changes for review, I create review early, describe intention of my changes in the comments and keep adding more changes to the review.  It would help me a lot if I was able to use same progress tracking, mark file revisions as read.  So when I add new changesets to the review, I can see what changes were brought in this iteration.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
The [Flyover Reports for Crucible add-on|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/biz.deref.flyover.flyoverForCrucible/server/overview] displays an "Incompatible" warning.
However, the [Atlassian Marketplace history page|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/biz.deref.flyover.flyoverForCrucible/server/versionhistory] indicates that it is supported by FishEye/Crucible.

h3. Environment
- FishEye/Crucible version 3.10.2
- Flyover Reports for Crucible add-on version 1.05.00

h3. Steps to Reproduce
- manually [install the add-on by file upload|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/UPM/Installing+add-ons#Installingadd-ons-Installingbyfileupload]. The add-on requires a manual install since it is not returned when accessing the Atlassian Marketplace from within FishEye/Crucible and searching for the Flyover Reports for Crucible add-on

h3. Expected Results
The add-on is returned by a search within Atlassian Marketplace.
The manually installed add-on does not display any warning

h3. Actual Results
The add-on displays an incompatible warning, as shown in the following screenshot:
!fecru_with_flyover-report.png|thumbnail!

h3. Notes
The vendor mentions the following on [their website|http://deref.co.nz/Flyover]:
{quote}
*Incompatibility Warnings*

Crucible currently reports the Flyover Reports add-on as incompatible with any version. Unfortunately this is a confirmed bug in Crucible, and the warning can be safely ignored. Version 1.05.00 functions correctly in Crucible 2.9 through 3.8.
{quote}

This is apparently caused by [FE-6275|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/FE-6275].
fields.summary: The Flyover Reports (3rd party) add-on for Crucible displays an incompatible warning

fields.description:
h3. Summary
When using a DCVS repository, in case the user uploads a patch based on a subsequent local change (any change after the first commit not being pushed to the "central repository"), the patch does not anchor.

h3. Environment
* DCVS repository, including:
** Mercurial
** Git

h3. Steps to Reproduce
The steps below refer to a Mercurial repository, but they can be applied to a Git repository as well.
# Provided that you have a Mercurial repository with a file in it
# Make sure all changes to the repository have been pushed to the central repository so that the {{hg diff}} command returns no differences
# Change a file in the repository local clone (let's call this change1)
# Commit the change (change1) without pushing it to the central repository through the {{hg commit}} command
# Create a second change in the repository local clone (let's call this change2)
# Create a patch file by using the {{hg diff}} command
# Upload the patch file as a pre-commit in order to create a review

h3. Expected Results
The patch anchors successfully to the repository.

h3. Actual Results
The patch does not anchor and the following appears in the +debug level+ {{atlassian-fisheye-YYYY-DD-MM.log}} file:
{noformat}
2015-12-11 16:33:05,843 DEBUG [qtp98826337-221 ] fisheye HgCache-resolveRevisionsForPatch - Unknown commit hash: 8ba4e47be4c7
2015-12-11 16:33:05,847 DEBUG [qtp98826337-221 ] fisheye TxHelperStylePlatformTransactionManager-rollback - Rolled back transaction started from:
java.lang.Throwable: (Stack trace at transaction depth 0 start)
        at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.SessionState.pushTxBeginStacktrace(SessionState.java:71) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.SessionState.beginTx(SessionState.java:61) [fisheye.jar:?]
        at com.cenqua.crucible.hibernate.HibernateUtil.beginTransaction(HibernateUtil.java:324) [fisheye.jar:?]
{noformat}

Where this is the result of the {{hg info}} on the file in the local repository (note the +commit hash matching the one in the stacktrace above+):
{noformat}
changeset: 	5:8ba4e47be4c7
tag:		tip
user:		test_user
date:		Fri Dec 11 16:30:55 2015 +11
summary:	change1
{noformat}

The FishEye user interface shows the following message (where patch3 is the patch name):
{noformat}
No repository found to anchor patch to
Crucible tried to anchor your patch to 'patch3', but did not find any matching revisions. You will not be able to do iterative reviews on this patch.
{noformat}
!Patch_not_anchoring.png|thumbnail!

h3. Notes
The SVN related use case is described in the [CRUC-6939|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-6939] ticket.

h3.Workaround
# Retrieve the commit hash of the last pushed revision by performing the {{hg log}} command
# When generating the patch, specify the retrieved commit hash:
{noformat}
hg diff -r c9ef90b58252 > patch1_and_patch2.txt
{noformat}
# Upload the patch_1_and_patch2.txt
fields.summary: A patch created on a subsequent local change not yet pushed to the central repository does not anchor to a repository

fields.description:
The FishEye [Linkers|https://confluence.atlassian.com/fisheye/linkers-298976904.html] functionality applies to commit messages only. But commit messages are often contain the same references to Crucible review descriptions and comments: e.g. developers refer to the same issue/bug ID in their bug tracker, and Crucible review descriptions are so many times exactly the same to commit messages. So it would greatly improve the review workflow if FishEye Linkers would work in Crucible text fields instead of having developers to use wiki markup for a functionality that works out-of-the-box in commit messages.

Also refer to this thread for the original idea: https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/32527955/fisheye-linkers-wont-work-in-crucible-comments
fields.summary: FishEye Linkers to work in Crucible comments

fields.description:
We've discovered and fixed a security issue, where the attacker could (using the REST API): 
* access the list of patches in a review (their filename, database id upload date and anchor details) without authentication
* access the patch content for any review as long as he had view access to any other review on the server
fields.summary: It is possible to access the list of patches in a review and their content by unprivileged users
Log forging vulnerability

fields.description:
See https://support.atlassian.com/servicedesk/customer/portal/17/CRC-9101

The layout of the projects page in the Crucible admin screens is almost unusuabe.

First, there's too many columns and no way to select which ones you want to view. To view the columns on the right you are forced to horizontally scroll.

BUT, the scroll bar is at the bottom, so you have vertically scroll to the bottom, slide the horizontal scroll bar over and scroll vertically back up to the project you want.

BUT, now you can't veiw left hand columns so you don't know which project is the one you want to view/click on the links for.

So, you scroll back down, move the scroll bar to the left, scroll back up until you see the desired project, highlight the entire row, scroll back down, scroll to the right and finally view/click on the columns.

Possible solutions which should all be implemented:

1. Add a search/filter box so you can view only the project you are interested in.
2. Add ability to choose which columns to view
3. Add paging to the list, BUT make sure you have navigation buttons on both the top and the bottom of the list.

And while I'm here, move the "Create New Project" button to the top of the page. It's silly to be forced to scroll to the end of the page to create a new project.
fields.summary: Admin Projects List Almost Unusable

fields.description:
We are having trouble obtaining review data including revision/repository info in an efficient manner. 

Here is our current approach
# We use Crucible's ReviewService.getCustomFilterReviews(filter, true) to get a list of ReviewData per crucible project.
# We go through this list and call ReviewService.getReviewDetails(reviewData.permaId()) which returns a DetailedReviewData object.  
# Populate our own object class from the DetailedReviewData object and return the data.

Our current approach can take a very long time (10+ mins) for some projects to return data.
https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/3.6.3/javadoc/index.html?com/atlassian/crucible/spi/services/ReviewService.html
fields.summary: Allow customised retrieval of review data using expandable API

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Currently if you have nested repositories such as a Git repository nested in a Perforce depot the {{crucible.py}} script will automatically choose Git as to create the patch. If you would like to create a Perforce patch the only way to do so is by modifying the script itself. 

h3. Workaround 

Making a copy of the current {{crucible.py}} to ignore the repo that has precedence. Do so with the following steps: 

# Edit the copied {{crucible.py}} file name to be something like {{P4_crucible.py}}. 
# Find the line {{return self.find_metadata_dir('.git')}} and modify it to {{return False}}
# Save the modification
# Run {{P4_crucible.py}} when you'd like to exclusively use P4.
fields.summary: Allow users to choose SCM for the crucible.py script
